user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fill_v1_form:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_form (const void *cls,
              const char *mime,
              struct Session *session,
              struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  size_t slen;
  char *reply;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  slen = strlen (MAIN_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1);
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
  if (NULL == reply)
    return MHD_NO;
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            MAIN_PAGE,
            session->value_1);
  /* return static form */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen,
                                                        (void *) reply,
                                                        &free);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    free (reply);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  add_session_cookie (session, response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_OK,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_form (const void *cls,
              const char *mime,
              struct Session *session,
              struct MHD_Connection *connection)
explanation:
I found no code constructs inside the function body that are statically unreachable: every return is conditional (early returns are reachable depending on runtime conditions), there are no statements following an unconditional return in the same execution path, no dead switch/case or labelled code that can never be reached, no infinite loops that hide later code, and no successive statements rendered unreachable by prior unconditional jumps within this function. Therefore none of the inner fragments (malloc/error branch, snprintf, response creation, header addition, queue/destroy/return) require investigation for Rule 2.1 as written.

One item that should be investigated at the translation-unit / project level is that the function is declared static. A static (file-scoped) function that is never referenced elsewhere in the same translation unit is effectively unreachable (dead) code. Whether this is a violation of MISRA Rule 2.1 depends on project-wide usage; that cannot be determined from this single function alone. Hence the static function declaration is reported for investigation. No other fragments inside the function indicate unreachable code.
